Package com.egehurturk.util

Interface HttpValues.Headers

Enclosing interface:
HttpValues
public static interface HttpValues.Headers
Header values that are both requested and responds These will be put in Map

  • Field Details

    • CONN

      static final java.lang.String CONN
      =========== GENERAL ============ Connection: controls whether or not the network connection stays open after the current transaction finishes. If the value sent is keep-alive, the connection is persistent and not closed, allowing for subsequent requests to the same server to be done. Connection: keep-alive Connection: close
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • ACCEPT

      static final java.lang.String ACCEPT
      ============= REQUEST ============= Accept: advertises which content types, expressed as MIME types, the client is able to understand. Using content negotiation, the server then selects one of the proposals, uses it and informs the client of its choice with the Content-Type response header. Accept: text/html Accept: image/* // General default Accept: star/star
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • ACCEPT_ENCODING

      static final java.lang.String ACCEPT_ENCODING
      =============== REQUEST=============== Encoding: The Accept-Encoding request HTTP header advertises which content encoding, usually a compression algorithm, the client is able to understand. Using content negotiation, the server selects one of the proposals, uses it and informs the client of its choice with the Content-Encoding response header CONTENT_ENCODING. Accept-Encoding: gzip Accept-Encoding: gzip, compress, br
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • ACCEPT_LANGUAGE

      static final java.lang.String ACCEPT_LANGUAGE
      ============= REQUEST ============== Language: advertises which languages the client is able to understand, and which locale variant is preferred. (By languages, we mean natural languages, such as English, and not programming languages.) Using content negotiation, the server then selects one of the proposals, uses it and informs the client of its choice with the Content-Language response header CONTENT_LANGUAGE Accept-Language: de Accept-Language: de-CH
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • CACHE_CONTROL

      static final java.lang.String CACHE_CONTROL
      ============== GENERAL ============ Cache Control: holds directives (instructions) for caching in both requests and responses. Cache-Control: max-age= Cache-Control: max-stale[=] Cache-Control: min-fresh= Cache-Control: no-cache Cache-Control: no-store Cache-Control: no-transform Cache-Control: only-if-cached
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • HOST

      static final java.lang.String HOST
      ============== REQUEST ============== Host: The Host request header specifies the host and port number of the server to which the request is being sent. Host: developer.cdn.mozilla.net (port is optional)
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • COOKIE

      static final java.lang.String COOKIE
      =================== RESPONSE ============= Cookie: contains stored HTTP cookies associated with the server (i.e. previously sent by the server with th- e Set-Cookie header or set in Javascript using Document.cookie). Syntax: Cookie: name=value Cookie: name=value; name2=value2; name3=value3 Example: Cookie: PHPSESSID=298zf09hf012fh2; csrftoken=u32t4o3tb3gg43; _gat=1
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • URL_RESOURCE

      static final java.lang.String URL_RESOURCE
      =============== REQUEST ============= Resource: The URL path associated with the request. This is where the HTML file lives in GET [/index.html] HTTP/1.1
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • METHOD

      static final java.lang.String METHOD
      =============== REQUEST ============= Method: The method associated with the request. [GET] /index.html HTTP/1.1
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • PROTOCOL

      static final java.lang.String PROTOCOL
      =========== REQUEST ============== Protocol: The protocol associated with the request. GET /index.html [HTTP/1.1]
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • SERVER

      static final java.lang.String SERVER
      ============= RESPONSE ================ Server: describes the software used by the origin server that handled the request — that is, the server that generated the response. Server: Apache/2.4.1 (Unix)
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • USER_AGENT

      static final java.lang.String USER_AGENT
      ================ REQUEST ================ User Agent: is a characteristic string that lets servers and network peers identify the application, operating system, vendor, and/or version of the requesting user agent. User-Agent: curl/7.64.1
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

      ============== RESPONSE ========== Date: contains the date and time at which the message was originated. Date: Wed, 21 Oct 2015 07:28:00 GMT
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • CONTENT_TYPE

      static final java.lang.String CONTENT_TYPE
      =============== GENERAL (POST IN REQUEST, NORMAL IN RESPONSE) =============== Content Type: is used to indicate the media type of the resource. In responses, a Content-Type header tells the client what the content type of the returned content actually is. Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=something
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • CONTENT_LENGTH

      static final java.lang.String CONTENT_LENGTH
      =============== GENERAL (POST IN REQUEST, NORMAL IN RESPONSE) =============== Content Length: indicates the size of the entity-body, in bytes, sent to the recipient. Content-Length:
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • CONTENT_ENCODING

      static final java.lang.String CONTENT_ENCODING
      =============== GENERAL (POST IN REQUEST, NORMAL IN RESPONSE) =============== Content Encoding: is used to compress the media-type. When present, its value indicates which encodings were applied to the entity-body. It lets the client know how to decode in order to obtain the media-type referenced by the Content-Type header. Content-Encoding: gzip Content-Encoding: compress Content-Encoding: deflate Content-Encoding: identity Content-Encoding: br // Multiple, in the order in which they were applied Content-Encoding: gzip, identity Content-Encoding: deflate, gzip

      Directives:

      • gzip
      • compress
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • CONTENT_LANGUAGE

      static final java.lang.String CONTENT_LANGUAGE
      =============== GENERAL (POST IN REQUEST, NORMAL IN RESPONSE) =============== Content Language: used to describe the language(s) intended for the audience, so that it allows a user to differentiate according to the users' own preferred language. Content-Language: de-DE Content-Language: en-US Content-Language: de-DE, en-CA
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

    • HTTP_V_1_1

      static final java.lang.String HTTP_V_1_1
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values
